item.title: From Academia to Data Science
item.description: Over the last years, many people have asked me: How do I enter Data Science? I don’t have a definite answer to this question, but having transitioned from an academic career in pure Mathematics to working as a Data Scientist, I have experiences that I can share.

item.title: Latency SLOs done right
item.description: In their excellent SLO-workshop at SRECon2018 (program) Liz Fong-Jones, Kristina Bennett and Stephen Thorne (Google) presented some best practice examples for Latency SLI/SLOs. At Circonus we care deeply about measuring latency and SRE techniques such as SLI/SLOs. As we will explain here, Latency SLOs are particularly delicate to implement and benefit from having Histogram-data available to understand distributions and adjust SLO targets.

item.title: Dynamic Tracing with GDB
item.description: Dynamic tracing is a very powerful debuging technique, that allows you to observe the behavior of running programs in a deep and meaningful way. People who have worked with Solaris or FreeBSD know about dtrace(1) and the great powers it gives you to dynamically observe the system behavior. It’s one of the things you really miss on Linux, once you have gotten to know it. If you have not heard about dtrace check out this collection of one-liners to get an idea of it’s capabilities.

item.title: All is loss
item.description: You might have heard, that most supervised Machine Learning methods boil down to minimizing a loss function over a set of parameters. I for myself was somewhat aware of this for a long time, but it was not until recently that I realized how powerfull this observation really is.

item.title: Circonus on the Raspberry Pi
item.description: There are a lot of interesting monitoring tasks, that can facilitated with a Raspberry Pi (e.g. here, there). Circonus does not officially support “Raspbian Linux on armv6/v7” as a deployment target, but given the steady interest in this topic, we took the time to pave the way and write down some instructions in this post.

item.title: Monitoring Dropbox
item.description: I keep a cheap little server in my basement. Amongst other things it contains a full checkout of my dropbox. In this way, I always have a copy of all my data inside of my walls. The content lies in the trusted hands of a zfs file system, which allows me to take regular snapshots, so I don’t loose data by accidentally deleting stuff on one of my devices. I just sleep better this way.
